title: Live: Aussies chasing mega bucks in IPL auction
text:
Live blog: Australians go under the hammer at the Indian Premier League auction February 20, 2017 11:05am by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS GLENN Maxwell, Pawan Negi, Murugan Ashwin – every year the Indian Premier League turns a select few rookies into overnight millionaires at the annual auction. 
But with that money comes a huge amount of pressure. 
The type of pressure that can derail a player’s campaign before it has even begun. 
That’s why it is important teams do their due diligence before pushing a seven-figure contract in a player’s direction. 
“I’ve been lucky - or smart - that we haven’t seen a player not cope but I’ve seen players in other teams struggle to deal with the added scrutiny that their price tag brings,” Woodhill, who has worked in the IPL since day one and has spent the past three seasons with Royal Challengers Bangalore, told Foxsports.com.au ahead of Monday’s auction. 
“Weight of expectation is massive and I’ve seen players not cope with that expectation... That’s where it’s important to determine who will and who won’t cope.” Mitchell Johnson in action for Kings XI Punjab last year. Source: AFP 
At Monday’s auction Woodhill will work closely alongside Bangalore head coach Daniel Vettori and the franchise’s key decision makers to secure the talent needed to bolster an already impressive roster. 
There are 30 Australian players up for sale, including star fast bowlers Mitchell Johnson and Pat Cummins. 
But just because their services are available, does not mean they are guaranteed IPL riches. 
Last year, Usman Khawaja, fresh off averaging 172.50 in the Big Bash League, went unsold at the auction – though he did eventually pick up a contract with the Rising Pune Supergiants, replacing the injured Hashim Amla. 
That same year, unknown Indian spinner Murugan Ashwin, who had played two List A games in his career, landed a contract worth $890,000. 
That’s the way things work in the IPL and there is some logic to the madness. Murugan Ashwin became a very wealthy man at last year’s IPL auction. Source: Twitter 
Firstly, every side must play at least seven Indian players each match, meaning high quality home-grown talent comes at a premium. 
And secondly, there is a belief that local talent is more likely to thrive in India than the big-name international. 
“It’s around recognising whether international players, who are doing well either internationally or domestically, have to ability to perform in the IPL... BBL form definitely doesn’t guarantee a high auction price or that you’ll be picked up at all. 
“The unknown Indian player is already comfortable in their surroundings. 
“They have been identified as players of talent through either local performances or state performances and it’s sometimes easier to help them settle into the IPL than it is for an overseas player. 
“T20 is a performance sport, whereas the Australian ODI team is increasingly picked on potential. T20 players are expected to perform and are paid to do so which brings a different kind of pressure as it’s tough to rebound from a poor season.”
